description: {"blocks":[{"key":"3c810","text":"Coregistration of data from imaged brains unto a brain atlas is one step to establish significance and legitimize differences in the densities/distributions of objects such as cells in the brain between separate channels or experimental cohorts. In this method, I provide a free, simple, and largely automated pipeline to coregister and analyze 3D mouse brain data using the tool ABBA, a free coregistration platform developed by Nicolas Chiaruttini, as well as some python scripts and ImageJ macros which I have developed. This protocol will go over preprocessing steps to prepare your image for import into ABBA as a serial, multi-channel .tiff image. It will provide instructions and tips on using ABBA to coregister 3D brains. Finally, it will explain a pipeline using python and the free imaging software ‘ImageJ’ to automatically obtain region specific information for all regions simultaneously, such as cell counts, cell densities, and a normalized, robust clustering factor that can safely be compared between heterogenous images, and provides a method for obtaining significance differences in regions between two cohorts regions based on the extracted information. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

groups.title: Human BioMolecular Atlas Program (HuBMAP) Method Development Community

status.info: We use this protocol and it's working

steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"9hn0","text":"The first step is to install ABBA1 and other necessary tools. Detailed instructions for ABBA installation can be found at https://biop.github.io/ijp-imagetoatlas/installation.html. Using Windows, installation of all ABBA dependencies can be easily accomplished by running an installer, but otherwise, each dependency will need to be installed individually per the instructions in that link. ABBA can also be installed through Python using pip. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sup","offset":33,"length":1},{"style":"UNDERLINE","offset":122,"length":57}],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":122,"length":57}],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"FFE57CF9FF2B11EE91370A58A9FEAC02","url":"https://biop.github.io/ijp-imagetoatlas/installation.html"}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"9bsb8","text":"Pre- and post- processing through this pipeline additionally requires the image processing software FIJI/ImageJ3 [https://imagej.net/software/fiji/downloads], which also must be installed for ABBA.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sup","offset":111,"length":1}],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":114,"length":42}],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"4F6A4610FF2C11EE91370A58A9FEAC02","url":"https://imagej.net/software/fiji/downloads"}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"4au4g","text":"Next, to follow these pre- and post-processing steps, download the python scripts and ImageJ macros from my github:  https://github.com/mclaughlinliam3/ABBA_Coregistration_Analysis_Tools.git","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"dhret","text":"Determining exact angular lineups, which will speed up coregistration in instances of misangled images, can be aided with the platform Imaris [https://www.oxinst.com/news/imaris-10-1-released], although the license is expensive, and this step can be safely skipped.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"2tk22","text":"Additionally, Python should be installed should be installed via the installer downloadable at: https://www.python.org/downloads/release/python-3123/. When prompted by the python installer, make sure the option to enable Python as an environment variable is enabled to allow its scripts to be run in any directory.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"UNDERLINE","offset":96,"length":53}],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":96,"length":53}],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"B26015DCFF2C11EE91370A58A9FEAC02","url":"https://www.python.org/downloads/release/python-3123"}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"11her","text":"Additionally, once python installed, please install the following modules by typing the following commands into the command terminal: ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"eb8mj","text":"pip install pandas==2.2.0","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9lpsc","text":"pip install numpy","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2kaqa","text":"pip install openpyxl","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8s3ia","text":"pip install tifffile","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"b7kss","text":"pip install scipy","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"13u6f","text":"Coregistration of data from imaged brains unto a brain atlas is one step to establish significance and legitimize differences in the densities/distributions of objects such as cells in the brain between separate channels or experimental cohorts. There are several services that provide such analysis for 3D brain images, however they are often costly and may occur outside of the laboratory preforming experiments. In this method, I provide a free, simple, and largely automated pipeline to coregister and analyze 3D mouse brain data using several pre- and post-processing scripts I developed, as well as the tool ABBA1 , a free coregistration platform developed by Nicolas Chiaruttini.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sup","offset":618,"length":1}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"356m0","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dgrq3","text":"The following method provides a free, fast, and accurate way to coregister mouse brains to the Allen Brain Atlas2, automatically obtain region-specific data on 800+ regions, and establish significant differences between regions of separate mouse cohorts. These steps allow coregistration to be performed in-house, providing a great degree of control over this analysis within a lab. Once a user is comfortable with this pipeline, a 3D brain image can be converted into region-specific data in around two hours each. An example of this pipeline is shown in Fig. 1. below.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sup","offset":112,"length":1}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f6qp6","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dlm83","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"dueti","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"image","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"height":183,"id":461889,"is_video":false,"legend":"{\"blocks\":[{\"key\":\"3sv00\",\"text\":\"Fig 1. This pipeline provides a fast, free, and largely automated way to accurately coregister 3D brain data and obtain quick results for all 800+ regions.\",\"type\":\"unstyled\",\"depth\":0,\"inlineStyleRanges\":[{\"style\":\"italic\",\"offset\":0,\"length\":155}],\"entityRanges\":[],\"data\":{}}],\"entityMap\":{}}","mime":"image/png","originalFile":{},"original_name":"image003.png","placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/qdcdb78yx.jpg","source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/qdcbb78yx.jpg","type":1,"webp_placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/qdccb78yx.webp","webp_source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/qdcab78yx.webp","width":550}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"5ogms","text":"Imaging techniques may widely vary, including 3D lightsheet images to serial 2-photon slices. However, be advised that the following tips will ease coregistration:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"9ep2m","text":"The brain should ideally be imaged perpendicular to either the coronal, sagittal, or horizontal axis. For optimal coregistration, the entirety of the brain in the intended coregistration plane should be imaged. As coronal coregistration is the easiest, optical or serial sections may want to encompass the entirety of the brain in the coronal plane if possible. Without the entire brain in the plane, the automated coregistration tools in ABBA will not function properly, permitting only manual coregistration.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"f6juk","text":"Additionally, coregistration will be easiest with a channel that provides a strong autofluorescent background signal for the brain and associated subregions, for easy matching of fiducials between image and atlas.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"eohvs","text":"This pipeline is designed for stitched tiff stack images. If the image field is taken over multiple tiles, it can be stitched using a program such as the free imageJ plugin BigStitcher: [https://imagej.net/plugins/bigstitcher/]. If the image is not in .tiff format, it can be converted using FIJI. Open the image stack in FIJI and select File-\u003eSave As-\u003eTiff.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"8cpk8","text":"Resave each channel as a tiff stack and complete the following same preprocessing steps on each: Depending on the specifications of the computer being used for downsampling, it may be a good idea to downsample the mouse brain data prior to coregistration. This may be accomplished using FIJI. Open the tiff image in FIJI and select Image-\u003eScale and designate downsampling parameters in the X and Y plane only (Fig. 3).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"20taa","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1jora","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"4shlr","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"image","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"height":462,"id":461893,"is_video":false,"legend":"{\"blocks\":[{\"key\":\"3uisg\",\"text\":\"Fig. 3. Downsample if necessary. The above image is being downsampled 4x in X and Y.\",\"type\":\"unstyled\",\"depth\":0,\"inlineStyleRanges\":[{\"style\":\"italic\",\"offset\":0,\"length\":84}],\"entityRanges\":[],\"data\":{}}],\"entityMap\":{}}","mime":"image/png","originalFile":{},"original_name":"image008.png","placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/qdchb78yx.jpg","source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/qdcfb78yx.jpg","type":1,"webp_placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/qdcgb78yx.webp","webp_source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/qdceb78yx.webp","width":550}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"7bm76","text":"ABBA allows coregistration along the sagittal, coronal, and horizontal axis. However, as fiducials are easiest to match in the coronal plane, resampling the image in the coronal axis will make the coregistration the easiest. Assuming it is perpendicular to one of the three major brain axis, resampling can easily be accomplished in FIJI. In FIJI, select Image-\u003eStacks-\u003eReslice (Fig. 4) and select the resample direction to transform the image into the coronal axis. Before coregistration, the image should begin with the olfactory bulbs at the start of the Z-stack (plane 1) and end with the brainstem at the end of the Z-stack. Additionally, the brain should be positioned the cortex on top. In the instance the brain is not aligned this way, it can be transformed in FIJI using the tools under Image-\u003eTransform (Fig. 5).  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"k9v2","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3t0vk","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"d61ro","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ecveh","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"7hco1","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"image","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"height":478,"id":461897,"is_video":false,"legend":"{\"blocks\":[{\"key\":\"7rjcm\",\"text\":\"Fig. 4. Reslice the brain in a new axis to make it coronal, if necessary. The above image is already positioned correctly, but if I applied the parameters on the right, it would reslice it starting from the \\\"top\\\" of the image, which would result in a horizontal axis slice.\",\"type\":\"unstyled\",\"depth\":0,\"inlineStyleRanges\":[{\"style\":\"italic\",\"offset\":0,\"length\":273}],\"entityRanges\":[],\"data\":{}}],\"entityMap\":{}}","mime":"image/png","originalFile":{},"original_name":"image010.png","placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/qdcmb78yx.jpg","source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/qdcjb78yx.jpg","type":1,"webp_placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/qdckb78yx.webp","webp_source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/qdcib78yx.webp","width":550}},"1":{"type":"image","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"height":477,"id":461901,"is_video":false,"legend":"{\"blocks\":[{\"key\":\"bqgf2\",\"text\":\"Fig. 5. Transform the brain to position it correctly, if necessary. The above image is already positioned correctly, but if it was not, I would use this window to rotate it into the correct position. Additionally, \\\"Flip Z\\\" may be used to position the olfactory bulbs near slice 1 if the brain is backwards.\",\"type\":\"unstyled\",\"depth\":0,\"inlineStyleRanges\":[{\"style\":\"italic\",\"offset\":0,\"length\":306}],\"entityRanges\":[],\"data\":{}}],\"entityMap\":{}}","mime":"image/png","originalFile":{},"original_name":"image012.png","placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/qdcrb78yx.jpg","source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/qdcpb78yx.jpg","type":1,"webp_placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/qdcqb78yx.webp","webp_source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/qdcnb78yx.webp","width":550}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"dbnok","text":"Because ABBA is limited in the number of planes it will process in parallel, it may be a good idea to reslice the brain along the coronal axis if there are an abundance of slices, such as in a lightsheet image. This may be accomplished using my reslice.py python script available at https://github.com/mclaughlinliam3/ABBA_Coregistration_Analysis_Tools.git. Run the script from the command terminal in the same directory as the image to reslice (Figs 6, 7). Input the image’s name in the console and select a reslice factor to generate an imaged resliced by that factor in the Z-plane, aiming to end up with a few hundred slices if possible, as too many will slow processing and too few will undersample the data. Ultimately, after downsampling and reslicing, tiff-images with channel files that were under 5 GB in size worked well for ABBA, while larger images may pose processing challenges. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fthq4","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7ietv","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"vu82","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"55lfh","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"761gq","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"image","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"height":257,"id":461905,"is_video":false,"legend":"{\"blocks\":[{\"key\":\"30b3q\",\"text\":\"Fig. 6: How to easily open the command terminal in a folder to run scripts (windows). Click the filepath bar in the windows explorer, type \\\"cmd\\\", and press enter.\",\"type\":\"unstyled\",\"depth\":0,\"inlineStyleRanges\":[{\"style\":\"italic\",\"offset\":0,\"length\":162}],\"entityRanges\":[],\"data\":{}}],\"entityMap\":{}}","mime":"image/png","originalFile":{},"original_name":"image013.png","placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/qdcvb78yx.jpg","source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/qdctb78yx.jpg","type":1,"webp_placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/qdcub78yx.webp","webp_source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/qdcsb78yx.webp","width":550}},"1":{"type":"image","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"height":363,"id":461909,"is_video":false,"legend":"{\"blocks\":[{\"key\":\"5ksju\",\"text\":\"Fig. 7: How to run the reslice script (Windows). Making sure the script and brain image are in the same folder as the command terminal, type \\\"python reslice.py\\\"  to start the script. The \\\"python\\\" command tells windows to apply the python compiler on whatever file is called. Input the name of the file, including the \\\".tif\\\" extension. Specify a reslice factor and press enter to run the script.\",\"type\":\"unstyled\",\"depth\":0,\"inlineStyleRanges\":[{\"style\":\"italic\",\"offset\":0,\"length\":394}],\"entityRanges\":[],\"data\":{}}],\"entityMap\":{}}","mime":"image/png","originalFile":{},"original_name":"image016.png","placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/qdczb78yx.jpg","source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/qdcxb78yx.jpg","type":1,"webp_placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/qdcyb78yx.webp","webp_source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/qdcwb78yx.webp","width":550}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"lre","text":"Transferring your image into ABBA requires first converting it into a new project in QuPath. Prior to transforming the image into a QuPath project, it should be turned into a set of serial images in a directory rather than a single tiff stack file. Open all image channels in FIJI and merge them into one using Image-\u003eColor-\u003eMerge Channel (Fig. 8).  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":340,"length":7}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ama89","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"174ui","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"b6of2","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"image","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"height":257,"id":461913,"is_video":false,"legend":"{\"blocks\":[{\"key\":\"2u5hv\",\"text\":\"Fig 8: Until this point, channels have been processed as separate files. Now, merge them back into one image.\",\"type\":\"unstyled\",\"depth\":0,\"inlineStyleRanges\":[{\"style\":\"italic\",\"offset\":0,\"length\":109}],\"entityRanges\":[],\"data\":{}}],\"entityMap\":{}}","mime":"image/png","originalFile":{},"original_name":"image017.png","placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/qdc5b78yx.jpg","source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/qdc3b78yx.jpg","type":1,"webp_placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/qdc4b78yx.webp","webp_source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/qdc2b78yx.webp","width":550}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"e40ja","text":"To ensure the brain image is imported into ABBA in its proper size, voxel-sizes (the true micro-or-milimeter size of the 3D pixel) may be verified at this point using Image-\u003eProperties (Fig. 9).  Please input the proper voxel sizes of the brain in the current XY plane into the image, which may have changed if the axis were shifted. Ensuring proper Z-axis size is not necessary. In addition, since the image will be warped onto the Atlas, correct voxel size is not actually needed as the image can be freely resized during coregistration, but this step will make initial alignment more straightforward. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":186,"length":7}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1a9f5","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"eve7m","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"image","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"height":393,"id":461917,"is_video":false,"legend":"{\"blocks\":[{\"key\":\"bbsh1\",\"text\":\"Fig. 9: Adjust the voxel sizes of the image, if necessary. Since the image will be resized during coregistration, these values do not actually matter but may make things more straightforward. Keep in mind that if the brain image was resliced into a coronal axis, the Z-axis which typically has different voxel sizes than X and Y will have been shifted into either X or Y. This may make the image appear stretched out, but if proper voxel sizes are designated, it will look normal when imported into ABBA.\",\"type\":\"unstyled\",\"depth\":0,\"inlineStyleRanges\":[{\"style\":\"italic\",\"offset\":0,\"length\":504}],\"entityRanges\":[],\"data\":{}}],\"entityMap\":{}}","mime":"image/png","originalFile":{},"original_name":"image.png","placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/qdc9b78yx.jpg","source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/qdc7b78yx.jpg","type":1,"webp_placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/qdc8b78yx.webp","webp_source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/qdc6b78yx.webp","width":550}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"264cv","text":"Save this image as a sequence in a new folder using FIJI by selecting File-\u003eSave As-\u003eImage Sequence, and choosing Tiff as the file format.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"42p3u","text":"If the image is only a single channel, please skip to step 12.7. Otherwise, the saved image sequence will not combine the channels from the same slice, which should be done before importing into ABBA if multiple channels are to be coregistered. To transform the image sequence containing multiple channels as separate images into an image sequence containing all channels in one image per section, first create a new directory.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"alkv3","text":"Open my channels_macro available at available at https://github.com/mclaughlinliam3/ABBA_Coregistration_Analysis_Tools.git in FIJI and select run (Fig. 10). There are several channels_macros, each which correspond to the number of channels they will assemble into one slice. See step 12.6 for more explanation. Note the first directory containing the channels to be merged should only contain the data that FIJI saved by the steps described above, or the channel macro may fail.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9p4lj","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"76teb","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9vagk","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"9foj0","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bk1rf","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"image","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"height":295,"id":461921,"is_video":false,"legend":"{\"blocks\":[{\"key\":\"e6s87\",\"text\":\"Fig. 10. To run macros in FIJI, simply drag them into FIJI and press run. To merge the serial, split-channel images into serial, multi-channel images, use the corresponding channel_macro. In the above example, I am merging two channels with channel_macro_2.\",\"type\":\"unstyled\",\"depth\":0,\"inlineStyleRanges\":[{\"style\":\"italic\",\"offset\":0,\"length\":257}],\"entityRanges\":[],\"data\":{}}],\"entityMap\":{}}","mime":"image/png","originalFile":{},"original_name":"image021.png","placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/qdddb78yx.jpg","source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/qddbb78yx.jpg","type":1,"webp_placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/qddcb78yx.webp","webp_source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/qddab78yx.webp","width":550}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"9gsvm","text":"When prompted, find the directory containing your serial images, and select the new directory to save the output. The channels macro will iterate through the first folder, combine the channels from the same slice together, and save the multi-channel slices in the output folder.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"10nli","text":"Tip: Note that this is intended to only work for sequences saved using the pipeline described above. In addition, there are multiple versions of the channels macro, each designed for a certain number of channels. Use “channel_macro_2” for two channel images, “channel_macro_3” for three channel images, “channel_macro_4” for four channel images, etc. Using the wrong channel macro will either fail or cause separate slices to merge as a multi channel image.  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":0,"length":459}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"dkrd3","text":"At this point, the image is ready to be opened as a QuPath project and exported to ABBA. First, create an empty directory and open QuPath. Drag and drop the empty directory into the project toolbar on the left side of QuPath (or use the “create project” ribbon). ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"69r41","text":"Next, select all the serial, multi-channel slices of the brain image and drag them into the left area of QuPath under “Image list”. When prompted, change the “Image Provider” option from “Default (Let QuPath decide)” to “Bio-Formats builder”, and uncheck “Auto-generate pyramids” (Fig. 11).  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bd9rf","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7elmn","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"bvh2d","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"image","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"height":401,"id":461925,"is_video":false,"legend":"{\"blocks\":[{\"key\":\"a5pe5\",\"text\":\"Fig. 11. Drag the serial, multi-channel slices into QuPath and open it with the above settings.\",\"type\":\"unstyled\",\"depth\":0,\"inlineStyleRanges\":[{\"style\":\"italic\",\"offset\":0,\"length\":95}],\"entityRanges\":[],\"data\":{}}],\"entityMap\":{}}","mime":"image/png","originalFile":{},"original_name":"image023.png","placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/qddhb78yx.jpg","source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/qddfb78yx.jpg","type":1,"webp_placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/qddgb78yx.webp","webp_source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/qddeb78yx.webp","width":550}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"8rnef","text":"An in depth, step-by-step tutorial to use ABBA can be found at https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sERGONVw4zE. This tutorial was created by the platform's developer, Nicolas Chiaruttini, and should be referenced for more detailed instructions. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":0,"length":241},{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":241},{"style":"UNDERLINE","offset":63,"length":43}],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":63,"length":43}],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"D3B84199FF4C11EE91370A58A9FEAC02","url":"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sERGONVw4zE"}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"6vdg1","text":"Start ABBA by searching for “ABBA” in FIJI and pressing “start”. When prompted, select “Adult Mouse Brain – Allen Brain Atlas V3p1” and the proper slicing plane, such as “coronal”.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"8ams7","text":"In ABBA, open your image by selecting [Import -\u003e Import Current QuPath Project] and finding the QPPROJ file associated with your QuPath project within the directory created for the QuPath project.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"d9sob","text":"When the images are loaded in, separate them by selecting “Change Overlay Mode”. To spread the slices out, manually move the first in the stack to the left and the last in the stack to the right, then select “distribute spacing”.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"eqv68","text":"It may be the case that a few slices were imported out of order. Check to make sure that the slices are in serial ascending order from left to right. If they are not, the slices can be selected and moved to their proper location. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"asv1e","text":"Next, increase number of displayed atlas slices to aid coregistration using the slider next to “Displayed slicing [atlas steps]. A display factor such as “8” is a good starting point.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"97bta","text":"Change the brightness on the Atlas and your image until both are easily visible.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"3nrki","text":"Finding proper alignment in the Z plane is the most important step to ensure good coregistration. In ABBA, this is accomplished by designating “key slices” where the imaged brain’s region fiducials match the atlas’s. Brain slices can be freely dragged to match their locations in the Z plane with the atlases. Ctrl+a can be used to drag all slices at once. However, any slices that are “designated” as key slices will remain rooted in place. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"c62p","text":"To start, find where the hippocampus first appears in the coronally-sliced brain and drag the entire brain until the hippocampus-slice matches where the hippocampus first appears in the Atlas. Select the hippocampus-slice and choose “set as Key Slice” (Fig. 12). Key slices may also be removed by selecting a slice and choosing “Remove Key Slice”.  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ep4br","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"77l65","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"7iiba","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"image","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"height":295,"id":461929,"is_video":false,"legend":"{\"blocks\":[{\"key\":\"3hsfb\",\"text\":\"Fig. 12. Example alignment of hippocampus appearance fidiciual. The atlas (yellow) and the brain image (green) have been matched for the slice where the hippocampus first appears coronally. Having found this match, I will mark this as a key slice and move onto matching other fiducials as keys, allowing ABBA to interpolate a Z-alignment.\",\"type\":\"unstyled\",\"depth\":0,\"inlineStyleRanges\":[{\"style\":\"italic\",\"offset\":0,\"length\":338}],\"entityRanges\":[],\"data\":{}}],\"entityMap\":{}}","mime":"image/png","originalFile":{},"original_name":"image025.png","placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/qddmb78yx.jpg","source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/qddjb78yx.jpg","type":1,"webp_placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/qddkb78yx.webp","webp_source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/qddib78yx.webp","width":550}}}}
{"blocks":[{"key":"e6m8d","text":"Ensuring Proper Angular Alignment ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"6tfjn","text":"If the brain image was not taken perfectly-perpendicular to one of the three brain axis, the angle of the atlas will need to be changed to permit proper alignment. If the brain image is already perpendicular and not angled relative to the atlas, skip to step 17.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"6ruub","text":"A perfect angle-adjustment can be obtained with the platform Imaris. If you do not have Imaris, skip to step 16.5. Download the Allen Brain Atlas v3 from [https://scalablebrainatlas.incf.org/mouse/ABA_v3] and convert both it and your brain into .ims images using the Imaris file converter.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"5u9ci","text":"Open your image in Imaris and import the Allen Brain Atlas over it by selecting File -\u003e Load Image.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"cjt1v","text":"The atlas can be freely rotated and translated using its frame that is generated when it is opened in Imaris. In the image frame corresponding to the Allen Brain Atlas, input 90° as the rotation factor and rotate and translate the Atlas until it is approximately aligned with your brain.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"8affm","text":"In the instance there is an angular mismatch, input 1° as the Atlas Rotation Factor and rotate it 1° at a time until it is angularly aligned with the brain image. Write down how many degrees it was moved in the X and Y planes.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"9i4h8","text":"In ABBA, input the number of X/Y rotation degrees with the rotation sliders beneath “Atlas Slicing” to rotate the Atlas into angular alignment with the brain image. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"5to83","text":"In the instance that Imaris is not available, rotation in X can be determined using symmetrical mismatches between your brain at the atlas. For example, if the right side of the brain has its hippocampus appear before the left side, the Allen Brain Atlas should be rotated to match this.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"66dp7","text":"In Y, rotation can be determined by moving the atlas at until the base and top of the brain in fiducial regions appear the same in the brain image and the Atlas.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"6pgmg","text":"For example, if the base of the brain image where the hippocampus appears is significantly shorter than the atlas, rotate the atlas forward in Y until these regions appear similar. Note that perfect angle is more difficult to obtain this way and may need to be readjusted throughout alignment, which will also require reassigning key slices.  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"dn3ie","text":"Once approximate angular alignment is obtained, continue to create key-slices at points where the brain image fiducials match the atlas. Note that angular alignment may need to be reevaluated throughout, which will require moving key slices.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"61bqq","text":"Other useful fiducials beyond the appearance of the hippocampus, in order in Z, are not limited to but include: ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4ibqi","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7nvi8","text":"The appearance of the Olfactory Bulb. ","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"71me3","text":"The appearance of the cortex (Frontal Pole) ","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"d153s","text":"The appearance of the ventricles. ","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9cuq7","text":"The appearance of the hippocampus ","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6gj1s","text":"The point where the hippocampus begins to descend in the cortex. ","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"891pv","text":"The point the hippocampus fully descends and connects with the lower cortex. ","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"87vtt","text":"The disappearance of the bright core of the hippocampus. ","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4l40c","text":"The full disappearance of the hippocampus. ","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6l3i1","text":"The disappearance of the cortex. ","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"d7m9l","text":"The appearance of the cerebellum. ","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9uedd","text":"Various fidicuals throughout the cerebellum (Cerebellar layers appear in the center before enlarging like rings and disappearing. These layers can be matched).","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"26b3b","text":"The disappearance of the cerebellum.","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6hghl","text":"Various other fiducials throughout, such as the descent of the hypothalamus, etc. ","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"dq92f","text":"After fiducials have been aligned, select “Distribute Spacing” to allow ABBA to interpolate the rest of the Z-alignment. “Distribute Spacing” can be utilized throughout alignment to assess the quality of the Z-alignment.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"4dsfo","text":"Tip: It may be the case that not all fiducials in Z can be aligned perfectly. For example, if the brain image has a rather large cortex that overlaps with the appearing cerebellum, whereas in the atlas, it disappears, there may be a few frames of slight mismatch. If this cannot be avoided, the more important region should be prioritized. Certain regions such as the hippocampus may take priority due to how they act as a major central anchor point for coregistration, but other regions can be instead prioritized if they are important for the experiment. In most cases, however, this will not be a major issue. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":0,"length":613}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"7a592","text":"Once Z-alignment has been completed, move on to XY alignment by selecting the “Review” mode (Z-alignment can be returned to by selecting the “Positioning” mode).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"fg0nd","text":"First, find an approximate alignment by navigating to a central slice, using ctrl+a to select all slices, and selecting Align-\u003e “ABBA - Interactive Transform”. Manually rotate, translate, and resize the brain slice in the X/Y dimensions until it is approximately aligned with the atlas.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"e24ht","text":"At this point, the current slice may appear well-aligned, however the alignment will not be consistent throughout all slices. However, now that the brain is overall in near-alignment, an automated affine transform may be used to create a strong, initial aligned state for all planes. Select all slices with ctrl+a and use align -\u003e “ABBA – Elastix Registration (affine)”, inputting the desired parameters. The affine transform will attempt to align all slices to the atlas, which may take several minutes (Fig. 13).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fvt7","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"b5kv","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"fve8e","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"image","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"height":199,"id":461933,"is_video":false,"legend":"{\"blocks\":[{\"key\":\"b64s2\",\"text\":\"Fig. 13. Example settings for an automated affine transformation. An affine transform will translate, rotate, and warp the brain onto the atlas and is essentially an automated alternative to the interactive transform. However, it will not perfectly handle heterogenously shaped regions, for which a spline transform (step 18.5) may be necessary.\",\"type\":\"unstyled\",\"depth\":0,\"inlineStyleRanges\":[{\"style\":\"italic\",\"offset\":0,\"length\":345}],\"entityRanges\":[],\"data\":{}}],\"entityMap\":{}}","mime":"image/png","originalFile":{},"original_name":"image027.png","placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/qddrb78yx.jpg","source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/qddpb78yx.jpg","type":1,"webp_placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/qddqb78yx.webp","webp_source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/qddnb78yx.webp","width":550}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"fjku9","text":"After completion, look through all slices to verify a decent initial alignment has been completed, comparing the before and after alignment by flipping between the previous and current registration. In certain cases, the affine alignment may not have worked well. If this occurs, remove the affine transform by selecting, then right-clicking the slices with the wrong registrations and selecting “remove last registration. For such slices, instead use the interactive transform option for a manual affine alignment.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"9l7f2","text":"Additionally, the brain imaged being clipped out of frame when originally imaged will make automated alignment in general fail, meaning these slices will likely require manual alignment alone. If lone manual alignment is utilized, one fast way to complete it is to select several similarly-sized, nearby slices and preform an interactive transform. Oftentimes, an interactive transform will work well for neighboring slices even when they were not the reference point. Use this method for several brain slices at once until the entire brain is approximately aligned.  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"bm749","text":"After the affine transform, a closer-alignment may be achieved using a spline transform. Select all slices and use Align -\u003e “ABBA - Elastix Registration (Spline)”, inputting the desired parameters (Fig. 14).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8a9fh","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"34dq0","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"33qd4","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"image","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"height":193,"id":461937,"is_video":false,"legend":"{\"blocks\":[{\"key\":\"abapj\",\"text\":\"Fig. 14. Example settings for an automated spline transform. A spline will differentially warp different parts of the image, allowing heterogenous regions to be stretched into the correct places.\",\"type\":\"unstyled\",\"depth\":0,\"inlineStyleRanges\":[{\"style\":\"italic\",\"offset\":0,\"length\":195}],\"entityRanges\":[],\"data\":{}}],\"entityMap\":{}}","mime":"image/png","originalFile":{},"original_name":"image029.png","placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/qddvb78yx.jpg","source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/qddtb78yx.jpg","type":1,"webp_placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/qddub78yx.webp","webp_source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/qddsb78yx.webp","width":550}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"737j9","text":"In many cases, the spline is sufficient to create a near-perfect alignment. However, like before, look through all slices after the spline and remove any that resulted in a worse registration.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"1dqmv","text":"Alternatively, failed splines can be manually edited by selecting Align-\u003e “ABBA - Edit Last Registration”, although this may be a time-consuming process. Additionally, splines may be manually generated from scratch using Align -\u003e “ABBA - BigWarp Registration”, although this is also time consuming and usually unnecessary. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"b3bgn","text":"It is often the case that a decent coregistration usable for analysis can be generated regardless if the spline is successful, however a successful spline will lead to a near-perfect coregistration.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"3rhok","text":"This manual alignment -\u003e Affine -\u003e Spline transform, with corrections throughout, is a general all-purpose method to accurately coregister the brain, however the manual, affine, and spline transforms may be repeated as needed.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"2c93l","text":"Important: Please note that certain other FIJI plugins may prevent the automated transforms from working correctly. If this is encountered, please download a new version of FIJI and only install the ABBA update site using Help-\u003eUpdate…-\u003eManage Update Sites-\u003e Search for the update site “PTBIOP” and select it -\u003e Apply and Close -\u003e Apply Changes. Use this version of FIJI when running ABBA. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":0,"length":390}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"6sflo","text":"Reminder: As stated in step 18.1, certain other FIJI plugins may result in the automated transforms not completing. Please download a new version of FIJI with just the ABBA update site if this is the case.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":0,"length":205}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"3jlm4","text":"Finally, the current alignment in ABBA may be saved and reloaded if coregistration cannot be completed in a single sitting using File-\u003eSave Sate (Or Load State). ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"4srhg","text":"At this point, the coregistered brain can be exported (Fig. 15). There are various export options, however to use the below analysis pipeline, select the desired slices to export (or ctrl+a to export all slices) and select Export -\u003e “ABBA - Export Registered Slices to ImageJ”-\u003e and choose the desired naming format under Atlas ROI Naming, such as “name” for full names.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"alv5p","text":"Input * under “Slices channels” to export all channels in one multi-channel image.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"3a48r","text":"Finally, designate the Pixel Size in microns. The default value of 20 microns per pixel is generally sufficient. The coregistered brain will be exported to FIJI, which may take around ten minutes. Once the export is finished, please save it as a tiff in FIJI.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5nnpa","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2hp7j","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"bvn7m","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"image","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"height":176,"id":461941,"is_video":false,"legend":"{\"blocks\":[{\"key\":\"f11hp\",\"text\":\"Fig. 15. Example settings for exporting the coregisetered brain. Please note the are several options for exporting the coregistered brain, but this pipeline will be for the settings specifically shown here.\",\"type\":\"unstyled\",\"depth\":0,\"inlineStyleRanges\":[{\"style\":\"italic\",\"offset\":0,\"length\":206}],\"entityRanges\":[],\"data\":{}}],\"entityMap\":{}}","mime":"image/png","originalFile":{},"original_name":"image031.png","placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/qddzb78yx.jpg","source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/qddxb78yx.jpg","type":1,"webp_placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/qddyb78yx.webp","webp_source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/qddwb78yx.webp","width":550}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"drca4","text":"Interacting with the Coregistered Brain in FIJI ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":48}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"b7vm4","text":"The brain image will now have been warped onto the Atlas. This exported image will have 20 µm voxel-sizes in both X and Y (Assuming the default pixel size parameters were not changed), while the Z-voxel size will be inconsistent and not utilizable as a measurement, although that will not effect this analysis pipeline. The regions will be stored in the image as an overlay. The regions may be interacted with using Image-\u003eOverlay. Use “List Elements” to list all regions. Double clicking a region in the Elements window will bring you to said region. Use “To ROI Manager” to convert the Overlay into ROIs that may be used for quantification or transferring the overlay onto segmented images. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Segmenting the Brain for Cells or Other Objects of Interest with Machine Learning
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"541q","text":"This section describes how to create a binary mask for cells in the coregistered brain data, which will be used for region-specific quantification. A binary mask reduces an image to only black pixels representing background or white pixels representing signal which enables computational analysis. This pipeline is intended for cells, but theoretically other stained structures such as axons could be segmented and analyzed with these steps as well. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Segmenting the Brain for Cells or Other Objects of Interest with Machine Learning
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"66uch","text":"All analysis steps beyond this point must be completed on separate channels individually. In the coregistered brain, separate channels in FIJI using Image-\u003eColor-\u003eSplit Channels (Fig. 16), then saving each as a tiff.  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"11p6s","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cekjn","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"6lra5","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"image","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"height":304,"id":461945,"is_video":false,"legend":"{\"blocks\":[{\"key\":\"ek447\",\"text\":\"Fig. 16. Once again, split the channels of the coregistered brain for individual processing.\",\"type\":\"unstyled\",\"depth\":0,\"inlineStyleRanges\":[{\"style\":\"italic\",\"offset\":0,\"length\":92}],\"entityRanges\":[],\"data\":{}}],\"entityMap\":{}}","mime":"image/png","originalFile":{},"original_name":"image033.png","placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/qdd5b78yx.jpg","source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/qdd3b78yx.jpg","type":1,"webp_placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/qdd4b78yx.webp","webp_source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/qdd2b78yx.webp","width":550}}}}

Repeat this process until the segmentation seems satisfactory. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Segmenting the Brain for Cells or Other Objects of Interest with Machine Learning
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"47qse","text":"Tip: While training in labkit, precise labelling should be used for better results. For example, if my cells look like white dots, I may select a white dot with red but circle its immediate surrounding pixels with blue, so the model knows to only select white dots and not nearby background. However, in areas with clumps of overlapping cells, I will highlight several interconnected white pixels with red so the model knows to select larger, fused signal if available. In the case of autofluorescent background that may appear similar to signal, I will trace them with blue in a way unique to only that autofluorescent region which cannot be construed with positive signal. For example, if the midline of the brain is highly autofluorescent, I will trace it all the way down with blue line in one stroke, so the model knows not to select very long, bright lines. If the edges of the brain are autofluorescent, I will trace the edge and the immediate background together with one stroke, so the model knows not to select bright regions that are immediately adjacent to very dark ones. An ideal model will select most positive signal and little background, prioritizing avoiding major false positives over selecting all signal.  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":0,"length":4},{"style":"italic","offset":5,"length":1221}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cqqok","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"894h8","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"fv54f","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"image","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"height":359,"id":461953,"is_video":false,"legend":"{\"blocks\":[{\"key\":\"87luh\",\"text\":\"Fig. 18. Various instructions on using labkit to segment. Labkit offers a more-specific and still fast segmentation alternative to simply applying a mathematical algorithm or threshold, with machine-learning segmentation being generally superior.\",\"type\":\"unstyled\",\"depth\":0,\"inlineStyleRanges\":[{\"style\":\"italic\",\"offset\":0,\"length\":246}],\"entityRanges\":[],\"data\":{}}],\"entityMap\":{}}","mime":"image/png","originalFile":{},"original_name":"image037.png","placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/qdedb78yx.jpg","source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/qdebb78yx.jpg","type":1,"webp_placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/qdecb78yx.webp","webp_source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/qdeab78yx.webp","width":550}}}}

This is a necessary step to ensure cell data can be calculated.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fg8hp","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7l4aj","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"dev75","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"d5u3i","text":"Additionally, select Image-\u003eProperties and correct the voxel dimensions so that the X and Y dimensions contain the value 0.02 mm (mm will be added under “unit”; this is assuming the exported data from ABBA had the default 20 micron/pixel value.
